lines: This semester you must decide where you would like to live, now that you are in college.
#LIVE ON CAMPUS IN ONE OF THE DORMITORIES
You will probably save some money by living at home.

You are assigned a roommate named Bonnie Castano. Although she seems like a nice enough person, she is extremely sloppy, is prone to turning the stereo up very loud, and spends most of her time seeking out and ingesting
federally-controlled substances. When you ask what her major is, she replies, "Partying! What else is there?" Does this seem like someone you can live with?
The two of you must be well suited for each other. I'll assume you have the same interests.
I'm sorry. There are no other room assignments available right now. You'll just have to see if you can work it out.

You are assigned a roommate named Bonnie Castano. When you walk into the room, a beautiful, shapely brunette walks out of the bathroom wrapped in a towel. When you get to know her she tells you that she is interested in "men,"
"partying,"  and "men."  Looks like the people who assign rooms put you with a free-spirited type. Does Bonnie sound like someone you can live with?
Great. She asks if you wouldn't mind clearing out for a few nights. She is expecting a male guest and things might get a little wild. Is this okay with you?
Bonnie tells you that you are outrageous. I guess you think she'll do the same for you sometime.

When you return to your room, you find that things HAVE gotten a "little wild." When you finally locate and reassemble your bed, you notice thick globs of dried macaroni and cheese stuck to the mattress. When you ask Bonnie what it is
Bonnie thinks you are being totally unreasonable and "uncool." After all, she would do the same thing for you, adding, "As long as it's not a Monday or a Friday or in September through March."
I guess she's just not your type. The college finds you someone much more to your liking to live with.
